results.title: Family tree
results.creator_credit: Evelyn Lambart, George Dunning, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: The story of the settlement of Canada, illustrated with cheerful animated cartoons. The arrival of Jacques Cartier, the fishing and fur trades which followed, and the rival colonization by the French and British, climaxed by the battle of the Plains of Abraham, are depicted. The coming of the United Empire Loyalists is seen; then the west-coast gold rush and the completion of the transcontinental railway. New branches were added to the family tree when many European settlers came to fill the great spaces of the Prairies. Finally, we see the whole country matured into a nation, its traditions enriched by those of many peoples.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Evelyn Lambart, George Dunning, Tom Daly and National Film Board of Canada

results.title: The Family: the boy who lived alone
results.brief_description: A young boy, Billy, runs away from home. As he walks, he observes others who appear lonesome. The film captures many of the thoughts Billy has about his family. After a wet, uncomfortable night in an abandoned house, Billy’s desire to become part of his family again increases and he decides to return home at daybreak.

results.title: Family recreation
results.creator_credit: Alex Ezard, Artransa Park Studios and Shell
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Fit to Live”.
Australians in most walks of life now have more leisure time at their disposal. There are many enjoyable, interesting and healthy ways of utilising this leisure time, and this film gives many suggestions - and much food for thought.

results.title: The Family prince
results.creator_credit: Jeannine Locke and Canadian Broadcasting Corporation
results.brief_description: A candid look at the relevance and romance of the British monarchy from Prince Charles, Prince of Wales. Bridging the Prince’s frank, on-camera comments, the narrative script is combined with historical film footage to study the evolution of Crown and Commonwealth in modern times and to look at Charles’ younger years.

results.title: Family portrait
results.brief_description: An impression, by the late Humphrey Jennings, poet, painter and film maker, of the spirit and traditions of Britain and its people. Made in celebration of the Festival of Britain, 1951. Credits include: music by John Greenwood; photography by Martin Curtis; narration by Michael Goodliffe; music direction by conductor Muir Mathieson.

results.title: A Family of Tokyo
results.brief_description: A working day and a holiday in the life of a Japanese middle-class family of a husband, wife and three school-age children. Shows the respective status, roles and functions of family members and the ble.ding of the traditional and modern in family life

results.title: Family of man
results.brief_description: A portrayal of the “Family of Man” exhibit on display in the US in 1955 and in Australia in which Edward Steichen describes and demonstrates various exhibit panels, and explains how photography can be used as an art medium to show the universal oneness and goodness of mankind.

results.title: Family day care
results.creator_credit: Karl McPhee, Robin Hughes and Film Australia
results.brief_description: Additional credits are: script- Karl McPhee; photographer- John Hosking; editor- Karl Sodersten; sound- Max Hensser, Julian Ellingworth. Pam Goodwin is one of the co-ordinators of a Family Day Care Program. Her job entails interviewing parents and helping them find the kind of care that they want for their children, and interviewing the women who want to mind children and helping them in this role.

results.title: Family camping
results.creator_credit: Edmund Reid and National Film Board of Canada
results.brief_description: For the family on a camping vacation for the first time, or even for the experienced camper, this color film is a congenial and informative guide. It shows popular forms of camping: site camping; a hiking trip; canoe camping in the backwoods; cruise camping through more travelled waters; and trail riding in the Rockies. Each is seen to have its own attractions.

results.title: The Family: an approach to peace
results.brief_description: Shows that the only way to peace is in the understanding of other peoples, and contrasts the popular conception of foreign lands with life as it actually is around the globe. Through scenes of everyday family life everywhere, describes the similarity of the fears and aspirations of all people.
